column2: An algorithm is simply a list of instructions that describe how to do a particular task.
The difference between the actual number and the nearest representable value.
A data type whose properties are specified independently of any particular programming language.
Picking out the important bits of information.
The part of the ALU that stores the intermediate results when doing a calculation.
A network attack where the hacker attempts to change data or introduce malware.
A step-by-step set of rules or instructions.
Coming up with an algorithm to solve a problem.
The collective name for letters, digits and symbols.
Arithmetic and Logic Unit. The part of the CPU that carries out mathematical and Boolean operations.
A continuous signal which can't be processed by a computer.
A logic gate with two inputs. The output will be on if both of the inputs are on. If either is off, the output will be off.
One of the Boolean operators. The result is true if both of the conditions are true. If either are false, the result is false.
Software designed to stop malware from damaging a computer or network.
Software for phones and tablets usually with one particular purpose.
A piece of software written to help users do various tasks, often through a graphical user interface with menus and toolbars.
A layer of software that allows application programs to call on the services of the operating system.
Describes how the CPU works and interacts with the other parts of the computer system.
A value that a parameter of a sub program actually takes.
An operator that programs use to carry out simple mathematical operations.
A data structure where all the data is stored and defined under one variable name.
A 7-bit character set consisting of 128 characters (8th bit is used as parity bit).
A program that turns assembly language into machine code.
A low-level language.
Assigns the value on the right hand side to the name on the left hand side.

Transmission system in which the sender and receiver have separate clocks which are not kept synchronised. Instead, the clocks are synchronised temporarily at the start of a transmission. The arrival of data cannot be predicted by the receiver; s a start bit is used to signal the arrival of data and to synchronise the transmitter and receiver temporarily.
A property or characteristic of an entity (databases) or an object (OOP).
A process for checking the identity of the user.
A programming tool commonly used to make a summary of a program.
Turning an abstraction into a form that can be processed by a computer.
A vulnerability in a computer or network's security that a hacker could exploit.
Software which can automatically create a copy of the files and settings on your computer at a given time. This will allows the users to restore work in the event of an error or issue.
The amount of data that can be transferred on a network in a given time.
The rate at which signals on a wire may change.
A counting system using base-2 consisting of Os and 1s.

The process of adding two binary numbers together. The rules for each digit: 1 + 1 = 0 with carry; 1 + 0 = 1 with no carry; 0 + 1 = 1 with no carry; 0 + 0 = 0 with no carry, 1 + 1 + carry = 1 with carry.
The process of converting binary numbers to or from decimal (Base 10).
The process of converting binary numbers to or from hexadecimal (Base 16).
When the binary number resulting from some arithmetic is to large for the available space, the overflow or carry flag is set.

A searching approach where a list is split in two. The target value is compared to the middle item and the half which cannot contain the target value is discarded. The process is repeated until the target value is found or the list is exhausted.
Moving the bits in a binary number left or right and filling the gaps with Os.
Basic Input Output System check. It checks that the computer hardware is all present and working correctly when you power up a computer system.
A binary digit, either O or 1.
The number of bits transmitted per second.
A graphic that is made up of pixels.
A list of inputs that a program should reject.
A logical system using the operators OR, AND and NOT. The Boolean data can take one of two values, either true or false.
A variable or statement which can have either a TRUE or FALSE value.
Logic circuits are special circuits built into computer chips. They receive binary data, apply Boolean operations and output binary results.
A set of words used as connectives to combine one or more statements or variables to produce either a TRUE or FALSE value.
Starting up a computer is also known as 'booting up' the computer.
A programming tool used to halt a program at a specific place.
A multiple data channel system in which the bandwidth of the transmission medium carries several data streams at the same time.
A network attack which uses software to crack security passwords through trial and error.
A sorting algorithm where during a pass, neighbouring values are compared and swapped. Passes are made until no further swaps are needed.
A network topology in which all devices are connected to a single backbone cable.
8 bits.
Quick access memory inside the CPU.
Very fast access memory which is close to the processor and stores frequently used data.
A way of changing from one data type to another.
Standards for copper Ethernet cables used on LANs.
The control (usually by a government or organisation) of what information other people can access.
A small range of Wi-Fi frequencies.
A single alphanumeric symbol.
A type of data which represents a single alphanumeric item. This could be the letter "a", an exclamation mark or a "non-printable" (invisible) item like a space or tab.
A group of characters that a computer recognises from their binary representation.
A digit added to a string of digits which is used to check if all the digits have been entered and read correctly.
A number used to check if a packet of data sent between network s has been received correctly.
Message data after it has been encrypted.
A computer that uses the services provided by a server.
A type of network managed by a server, which takes requests from client devices.
A system in which some computers (the clients), request services provided by other computers, the servers.
The speed at which the processor carries out instructions, measured in Megahertz (MHz) or Gigahertz (GHz).
The use of the Internet to store files and provide software. Also known as the cloud.
Part of an IDE where you write and edit your source code.
The number of bits used for each pixel in an image file.
A text-based user interface where the user types in commands.
A note added to source code to say what part of a program does.
A set of agreed signals, codes and rules to be used for data and information exchange between computers.
Compares two values and outputs either true or false.
An executable file created by a compiler.
A programming tool to translate source code into machine code.
Taken to be the worst case complexity of the most efficient algorithm which solves the problem.
The process of making the size of a file smaller.
A measure of how economical an algorithm is with time and space.
Tackling a problem through decomposition, abstraction and algorithmic thinking.

Legislation which is designed to protect users from attacks or theft of information. Offences under the act include Hacking, unauthorised access to a computer system or spreading malicious or damaging software (e.g. viruses)
A computer system takes a set of inputs, processes them and creates a set of outputs using hardware and software.
Joining strings together.
An iteration statement that repeats a set of instructions until a condition is met.
A named value which cannot be altered as the program is running.
The part of the CPU that controls the flow of data.
Legislation which gives the creators of software (or other things such as paintings, books or music) the right to control the ways in which their material may be used.
A processing unit found inside the CPU.
An iteration statement that repeats a set of instructions a given number of times.
Central Processing Unit also called as Processor.
Ways in which the speed at which the CPU process instructions can be affected (e.g. improving the clock speed, increasing the number of cores or adding more cache memory)
Permits sharing of a creative work as long as certain requests from the original creator are upheld.
A method of trying to find the plain text from the cipher text without the decryption key.
The science of designing cipher systems.
Control Unit
An issue which affects a particular religious, ethnic, national or other group.

column1: Custom Written Software Or Bespoke Software
column2: The software system which is designed and developed specifically for a purpose or company.
Using social media to deliberately harm someone else.
Legislation which controls how an individual's personal information may be used or kept by the organisations, businesses or government bodies which process it.
Movement of data.
TelIs you what kind of data it is, e.g. integer, real, string, etc.
A structured collection of data.
Identifying and fixing errors in a program.
Breaking a problem down into smaller problems.
Using an algorithm and a key to convert encrypted message data into its plain text equivalent.
A computer system designed to carry out a specific task.
A method of designing a program so that it functions properly and doesn't crash.
Reorganising data on a hard drive to put broken up files back together and collect up the free space.
A number system using base-10. Also known as decimal.
The process of converting decimal numbers to or from binary (Base 2).
The process of converting decimal numbers to or from hexadecimal (Base 16).
A network attack which stops users from accessing a part of a network or website.
Part of the Copyright Legislation which protects the planning stages and unique properties of creative items from being copied without the consent of their creator.
A piece of software that allows applications to communicate with a piece of hardware.
The inequality created by the fact that some people have greater access to technology than others.
The representation of an analogue signal using binary data.
Organisation and maintenance of the hard disk.
With a monocle.
Type of iteration statement.
A server which stores website domain names and their IP addresses.
A small piece of hardware which allow devices to connect to a network wirelessly.
dots per inch
Memory space is only allocated when required at runtime.
An IP address which is automatically assigned to a device before it accesses a network.
Content that is generated when the web browser request is received.
A further logical check performed when the previous statement resulted in a FALSE outcome. It allows multiple conditions to be checked for their truth value.
A dedicated computer system with a limited or non-existent user interface and designed to operate completely, or largely, autonomously from within other machinery.
A computer built into another device, e.g. a SmartTV.
Coding ('encrypting') data so that it can only be decoded ('decrypted') with the correct key.
An object, person, event or thing of interest to an organisation and about which data are recorded.
An issue relating to how we impact the natural world.
Test data that a program isn't designed to accept.
Information about an error once it's been detected.
A failure or fault in a computer program which causes it to produce an incorrect or unexpected result, or to behave in an unintended manner.
Network protocol used on LANs.
Something which raises questions of right and wrong.
Discarded computer material.
Growth that has the form kn, e.g. 2n where k = 2 and n = 1, 2, 3, etc.
An algorithm whose execution time grows exponentially with input size.
An 8-bit character set consisting of 256 characters.
Test data on the boundary of what the program will accept.
A study that investigates the potential of a new system.
The process that the CPU uses to retrieve and execute instructions.
A high performance cable that uses light to carry data.
A column of a database used to store a category of data.
Reading from and writing to external files.
The organisation, movement and deletion of files.
Copying files between devices on a network.
When the testing stage of the software development cycle is only done once to check the software meets all the initial requirements.
Permanent software stored on ROM, used to control hardware or embedded systems.
A technology for storing data in an electronic format which is used for memory cards. e.g. USB, memory cards.
A flowchart is a diagram which shows the breakdown of an algorithm into all of the necessary steps and is alternative to Pseudocode.
A type of count-controlled iteration statement.
The unit used to send data via Ethernet over a LAN.
Legislation which provides public access to information held by public authorities.
Transferring files over the internet using File Transfer Protocol.
A sub program that takes parameters and returns a value.
A type of testing that assesses how well a program meets the requirements.

1000 megabytes.
The digital divide between different countries.
A variable which can be accessed by any line of code within a program

A piece of hardware containing a GPU.
Graphical User Interface
An IDE tool for giving a program a graphical user interface.
A person who tries to illegally access or attack a computer network or device.
The sending and receiving devices exchange signals to establish that they are each ready to initiate data transfer.
Traditional internal storage for PCs and laptops that stores data magnetically.
The physical parts of a computer system.
A type of CPU architecture which uses physically separate memory locations and busses to store and transport both instructions and data
Hard disk drive
Pulls heat away from the CPU to help maintain its temperature.
A counting system using base-16 consisting of the digits 0-9 and the letters A-F.
The process of converting hexadecimal numbers to or from binary (Base 2).
The process of converting hexadecimal numbers to or from decimal (Base 10).
A programming language, like C++ and Java, that is easy for humans to understand.
When a business uses its servers to store the files of another organisation.
A location where people can access a wireless access point.
Hyper Text Transfer Protocol
Hyper Text Transfer Protocol (Secure)

The PCs on a network are connected to a 'switch'. A switch manages lots of connections with computers at the same time and lets them all communicate with the server. This job was done by Hub at the past which couldn?t handle all connections.
The study, planning and design of what happens when a computer and human work together.
When web pages are requested and then sent over the Internet, another protocol is used in addition to TCP/IP which is the http.
Integrated Development Environment
Type of selection statement.
Pictures stored within a computer.
A protocol used to retrieve emaiIs from a server.
A record of all the changes since the last incremental backup.
Spaces put at the beginning of lines of code to help show a program's structure.
Removing unwanted characters from an input.
Checking that an input meets certain criteria.
A sorting approach where the next item in an unordered list is placed, or inserted, in it's correct place within an ordered list
A network attack where someone within an organisation exploits their network access to steal information.
A numerical data type for whole numbers.
An original piece of work (or an idea) that someone has created and belongs to them.
The ultimate/biggest/best WAN in the world, based around the TCP/IP protocol.
A translator that turns the source code into machine code and runs it one instruction at a time.
The protocol responsible for packet switching. Internet Protocol
An IP address is an address given to any piece of equipment on a network.
A statement which makes the program repeat a set of instructions.
Repeated testing done during the development of a program.
1000 bytes.

A Local Area Network (LAN) is a network where the workstations are 'close' together. It is usually thought of as computers in the same room, or building or even in a number of buildings, which are next to each other.
Checking data on a network for cyber security purposes.
Groups of protocols that have similar functions.
An issue relating to what's right and wrong in the eyes of the law.
Starts at the beginning of the list and compares each element in turn with the required value until a match is found, or the end of the list is reached.
A searching approach where a target value is compared to each item in a list, one after another, until the target value is found or the end of the list is reached.
An algorithm that executes in O(n) time.
A programming tool which can combine different compiled codes.
An open source operating system.
A collection of elements with an inherent order.
A variable that is only defined and usable within certain parts of a program.
An electronic circuit for performing logic operations on binary data. It may have more than one logic gate and more than two inputs.
When a program does something that was not intended.
An electronic circuit component that performs a Boolean operation (e.g. AND, OR or NOT).
A set of instructions that the program repeats until a condition is met or count is reached.
Temporarily removing data from a file to decrease the file size.
Permanently removing data from the file to decrease the file size.
A programming language that is close to what a CPU would actually do and is written for specific hardware (i.e. CPU type). e.g. machine code and assembly languages.
A unique identifier assigned to a device that cannot be changed. - media access code
The lowest-level programming language consisting of Os and 1s. CPUs can directly process it as a string of CPU instructions.

These devices store binary data patterns as billions of magnetised areas on a disk. These areas can be read from or written to by a special head that moves over the magnetic area. e.g. HDD(Hard Disk Drive)
The control unit, ALU and cache.
An extremely powerful (and expensive and reliable) computer for specialist applications.
How easy it is to fix bugs, change parameters and respond to changing requirements.
Fixing bugs, changing parameters and responding to changing requirements.
Malicious software created to damage or gain illegal access to computer systems.
A CPU register that holds memory addresses (locations) for data and instructions that the CPU needs. memory address register
A CPU register that holds data and instructions. memory data register
1000 kilobytes.
Hardware used to store data that a CPU needs access to.
A sorting approach where a list is split into individual items, these are then sorted as pairs are combined, or merged, together into ordered lists
A network topology where every device is directly or indirectly connected to every other without a central switch or server.
Extra data stored in a file which gives information about the file's properties.
An abstraction of an entity in the real world or in the problem that enables an automated solution. The abstraction is a representation of the problem that leaves out unnecessary detail.
The main circuit board in a computer that other hardware connects to.
A processor with more than one core (processor circuit) which means it can fetch and execute more than one instruction at a time.
When an operating system runs multiple programs and applications at the same time.
When an operating system allows multiple users at the same time.
A selection statement made up of multiple IF statements inside each other.
Investigations that organisations undertake to find the cause of attacks on their network.
A set of rules and procedures an organisation will follow to ensure their network is protected against attacks.
Protection against network attacks.
4 bits.
An internal piece of hardware that allows a device to connect to a network. - network interface controller
Memory that retains its contents when it has no power.
A type of test data that simulates the inputs that users are likely to enter.
A logic gate with one input. The output will be on if the input is off. If the input is on, the output will be off. Also known as an invertor.
Off-the-Shelf is the sort of software you use it at home or school. e.g. word processor, spreadsheets, databases etc.
Software that can be modified and shared by anyone.

To manage the hardware resources in order to provide for an orderly and controlled allocation of the processors, memories and I/O devices among the various programs competing for them and manage the storage of data. It hides the complexities of the hardware from the user.
A special symbol like +, *, =, /, AND, ==, that carries out a particular function.
CD, DVD or Blu-Ray disc that is read from/written to with lasers.
Device used to read and write to optical discs.
Optical devices store binary patterns using lasers. e.g. CD- ROM, DVD, Blu-ray disk.
A logic gate with two inputs. The output will be on if either, or both, of the inputs are on. If either both are off, the output will be off.
One of the Boolean operators.
Of a problem is its big O complexity.
A piece of software responsible for running the computer, managing hardware, applications, users and resources.
Running a CPU at a higher clock speed than was intended.
The result of a calculation is too large to be represented using the available number of bits.
An error that occurs when the computer attempts to process a number that has too many bits for it to handle.
A network in which all devices are equal and connect directly to each other.
The process of directing data packets on a network using routers and the IP protocol.
Small, equal-sized units of data used to transfer files over networks.
Multiple bits are sent down several wires simultaneously.
A variable that a subprogram requires in order to run - it's only defined within the sub program.
A bit placed at the end of binary data to show if it's been received correctly.
Where a hacker monitors data travelling on a network.
A string of characters that allows access to certain parts of a computer or program.
A licence that protects new inventions, ideas and concepts.
The part of a packet with the actual data.
Holds the memory address of the next CPU instruction. Program Counter
A network that has no dedicated servers. All computers are of equal status and can both share resources themselves and use resources from other computers, ie they are peers.
The process of simulating attacks on a network to identify weaknesses.
A peripheral is any hardware device which is connected to the computer and controlled by CPU.
External hardware connected to a computer. e.g. Mouse, Keyboard, Projector.
1000 terabytes.
When a phisher changes DNS server information so that customers are directed to another site.
When someone tries to get you to give them your personal information.
When criminals send emails or texts to someone claiming to be a well-known business.
Small dots that make up a bitmap image.
Message data before it is encrypted.

A piece of hardware that gives the other pieces of hardware the energy they need to run.
The maximum number of significant digits that can be represented.
An attribute or set of attributes which uniquely identifies a tuple.
Memory that can be accessed directly by the CPU.
A universal machine is a machine capable of simulating any other machine.
Each element of a priority queue has an associated priority.
Used to refer to the factors, techniques and technologies to protect sensitive or personal information on the internet.
IP address is used on LANs.
A subprogram that carries out a list of instructions.
The execution of program instructions by the CPU.
A set of instructions that can be executed on a computer.
The order in which statements are executed in a program (controlled with selection and iteration statements).
the act of writing program code
Software where modifying and sharing is not permitted.
When two devices want to successfully communicate, they must agree to follow some rules about the way they will do it. These are known as ?protocols?.
An early or trial working version of the proposed system developed to test possible solutions.
Building a working model, demonstration system, simplified version, rough copy or trial piece of software to help an analyst.

Describes content which has no copyright attached to it.
IP address is used on WANs.

Random Access Memory. This is the place where the computer stores programs and files it is using at the moment.

A temporary data store inside a CPU.
The absolute error divided by the actual numbers.

The density of pixels in an image, often measured in dpi (dots per inch).

The program will function reliably and not crash or go into infinite loops, even with incorrect inputs or unpredictable values.
Read Only Memory. ROM holds part of a program that starts running when a computer is switched on.
A device that receives packets or from one host (computer) or router and uses the destination IP address that they contain to pass them correctly formatted, to another host (computer) or router.

repetitive strain injury

External data storage used to store data so that the computer can be switched off.

Single bits are sent one after another along a single wire.
A device which provides services for other devices (clients), e.g. file storage/web pages/printer access.
Where people make money from things they already own.

Those digits which carry meaning contributing to the accuracy of a number. This includes all digits except leading and trailing zeros where they serve merely as placeholders to indicate the scale of the number.

How fast an algorithm runs, expressed as a function of the number of input values.
